Definitely an amazing game that I want to see and play more of. One of the 
best things about it is the lack of micro transactions, there's no easy way 
to beat the game but to relax and enjoy the ride. I played through the 
original D&D and I'm enjoying this one just as much. I do have two small 
gripes overall though after hitting 90%+ completion; lack of loot and 
unbalanced resources. The loot system works as a three piece set dependant 
on each characters class and is automatically applied with no user input. 
You are hard locked into a specific play style based off your classes, 
which would be fine if I wasn't lvl 53+ on all characters with only one 
class early unlocked as far as it can be. If there could be an advantage 
for playing a different class it is almost immediately lost because of how 
low it's affinity is and how difficult it is to find nuggets and shards. 
Golz and upgrade material are very limited resources from what I've seen. I 
grinded through as many sidequests as possible early on to farm golz and 
still had allot of trouble keeping my different classes' gear up to spec. 
As I mentioned above I also had trouble upgrading each class due to a lack 
of nuggets and shards. I ended up picking one class of each character and 
stuck with them through most of the game until I had extra resources to 
spend. To be fair these aren't game breaking or otherwise horrible, just 
design choices that I don't agree with 100%. If you like old school RPG's 
I'd recommend this and the original above all else in the Play store.

This is an edit to my original review. I wasn't crazy about the game at first. I still think  it could use a lot of work on the "flow". The main game does¬†have a sequence...¬†There are quests that lead to other quests in an orderly fashion, but after the main game "ends" there is much, much more to do. There were so many updates that is wasn't easy to know where to go and what to do in the best order. That being said, this a long game with plenty to do. Things did get very interesting the closer I¬†got to actually¬†being "done". Even after finishing, the arena fighting went on from there...¬†  I enjoyed the arena more than a lot of the regular game and I'm usually not crazy about purely fighting games, but with the rewards being more resources and other upgrades to fight with, it was a lot of fun.¬†I'm not nearly as versed with¬†rpg's¬†as I'm sure most of the players here are. Judging from the few I have played, this one is good.¬†I would recommend the game. Although the original is better, you really can't go wrong with this one considering the price. I will say that if you're looking to complete the game 100% you will likely be disappointed. From what I've seen in the forums and in the arena, there weren't many players that did complete it. There's¬†quite a bit that isn't really worth bothering with and¬†isn't necessary and there is not a full¬†walkthrough¬†to be¬†found. You'll¬†find¬†pieces of information in the forum, but even in there, as in the game at times, it's difficult to navigate.¬†A bit of advice for any new player... time to figure out¬†AutoCast¬†(main play) and¬†AutoBattle¬†(arena)... (they're the same thing).¬†It's quite confusing and for most of the game I didn't bother with it. Once I got serious about arena fighting it became essential to learn. Even after jamming my way to first¬†place in the gold league, I didn't understand parts of it. I decided to go back into the game to try to complete more of it, at that point I played around with AutoCast¬†until I finally figured everything out. After that, getting some of the achievements I hadn't done and looking for more of the secrets was a lot easier. The last word here is... TAKE THE TIME TO FIGURE OUT¬†AUTOCAST/AUTOBATTLE¬†earlier, rather than later. Just play around with it until you get it. Trust me... It will be worth it. Did I mention there are three final bosses... The last one was probably the most challenging I've ever fought in any game. Kudos to the developers for really putting their all into this.

There are great aspects to this game, but it has some major flaws. The grammar is AWFUL and can make it challenging to figure out what you're supposed to do in various quests. Not just grammar either, but the English is very broken and confusing. The overall flow of the game is quite disjointed, leaving you wondering what order you're supposed to do things in and discovering later that you missed entire main quests that you should have already completed. It's okay to have multiple side quests going on in random order but the main quests shouldn't feel all jumbled. Additionally,  there are apparently some bug issues with the spaghetti temple and a figure 8 you're supposed to walk. When you begin the figure 8 in the starting square, the altar should light up and get brighter as you walk around in the proper path.  But for some of us, the altar never activates at the starting square so no matter how many perfect figure eights you walk, the monster will never appear, meaning you can't progress in that part of the story. There are also numerous areas of the map that you can't reach with no explanation as to why or when it will be available. Why release a game that's only partially finished?! Overall, I'm frustrated because after 60 hours of game play, I can't progress in the game because of a bug. I've wasted so much time on this game, I wish I had never ordered it.

replyContent: Hello Robyn, thank you for the feedback! We are considering your suggestion for a futher update. One of the bigger advantages of the new system is that you can play one-handedly in many situations where on doom1 you had to keep both fingers on the screen. Like laying on the bed or on a bus or subway.
